This game is the sports version of 4x Turn Based Strategy games:

EXPLORE: That is the scouting of all those players throughout the minors and internationally

EXPLOIT: Use your staff to develop your players better; tweak the development and usage to make special units like POWER PITCHERS, SLUGGERS, and the most feared of all, RANCE MULLINIKS.

EXPAND: Use your specially developed players and free agent mercs to create a Dynasty organization

EXTERMINATE: Proceed to go 110-52 every season but lose in Game 7 of the World Series

This is my new podcast game (replacing the champ, Civ5, after 15 years) and represents a genre that doesn't get nearly enough love (sports management games). Even if you are a casual baseball fan, if you love 4x games then try this.

Quite simply, if your Jones is about immersion there is no better sporting management game. I used to be all about FM.. but whilst not as sexy, OOTP 26 has it all in terms of creating a universe with a pulse and enough levers and depth and observable connection between action and outcome that makes it fun and sometimes random but does not reward min-max game-play. It's about making decisions but really understanding that like life, there are many variables and in another time another place a different outcome might occur. 
I don't know much about baseball, but this is my game. I just love that its so replay-able, and of all the games its the closest to replicating the rhythm and data of a real sporting universe.
Don't get hung up on the 3D game aspect - I love it, but you have to note that its just the games attempt to describe what has already occurred in probability dice-rolls.. I originally would get upset when a player would field a ball with heaps of time to make a throw to make a double play according to the 3D in front of me.. but wouldn't do it.. forget that,. the real thing that occurred is the dice-roll that said the double play didn't occur - the 3D is just the games best approximation to replicate that... its the only real uncanny-valley style thing that can grind. unless you accept that fact.. 
It's just the best sports management game bar none. 
But it took me 5 version purchases across 10 years before I 'got it'... once you do though,, say goodbye to your other games.. you won't be playing them much anymore... :)

Out of the Park Baseball 26 is the ultimate baseball management experience for anyone who loves the sport beyond the field. You are not swinging the bat here. You are behind the desk, calling the shots, building rosters, making trades, and shaping the future of your franchise one spreadsheet at a time.

This year’s version adds a few great features that make it stand out. The inclusion of the World Baseball Classic mode adds an international touch and gives you something new to manage outside of the usual MLB grind. The updated Player Development Lab is also a big improvement, letting you see progress more clearly and make smarter decisions about how to grow your players.

What makes the game so rewarding is its depth. You control everything, from scouting reports to in-game strategies like when to steal or shift defense. Every choice matters, and when your team wins because of a trade or lineup change you made, it feels genuinely satisfying. The 3D match view continues to improve and adds a nice visual payoff for all the planning that goes into each season.

It is not perfect, though. There are still occasional bugs and a few interface quirks that can slow things down. Long-time players might feel that the jump from last year’s version is more evolutionary than revolutionary. But the core gameplay loop remains one of the best in any sports simulation out there.

If you love baseball, statistics, and the thrill of long-term strategy, OOTP delivers exactly what you want. It is complex, rewarding, and endlessly replayable.

Alright, overall I'm in love with the game and really addicted to it, but there are things that I dislike or even hate.

- RNG is too much. Team that easily swept season and postseason of one year, next year becomes irrelevant. No injuries, stats didn't drop drastically and mostly increased, opponent teams are not a lot stronger, but when 80 OVR SP has ~5.00 yearly ERA, It doesn't make any sense. Why he still scored that high by scouts if he doesn't perform over the year? And the opposite, when 45 OVR hitter outperforms everyone, but still counted as 45?
- Roster AI is stupid. It only looks on player stats, not actual baseball stats. It means a lot more micromanagement, which is fine if it wasn't so fucking inconvenient. 
- Roster management is ass. In times when players become inelligable for minor roster, there is no way to tell which players are inelligable outside of bar that appears on the screen when you finish the day. Players there are not even sorted. It's the pain in the ass to sort it out. Same for promotions. I cannot see baseball stats of the players outside of minor league report. It's fine, but it refreshes every time I make roster adjustment so I should find players all over again and it makes me crazy. 
- Sometimes salaries don't make any sense. Bidding war vs AI opponent is an ass. 30 year hitter asks for 7 year contract for 50 mils is insane. It's was 28 mil before bidding war! Everybody now is Juan Soto and every team is Mets.
- No ways to controllably earn money outside of ticket price. It would be much better If there was an option for merch distribution, advertIsing on stadium. Maybe even using star players as advertising material? MLB the show BTW has advertising options.
- I't feels more like I playing as team manager with player trading priviliges, not GM. While it's fun to walk prospects from minors to the World Series, there are not much options what to do as GM.
- You can't ask player to learn new position. In development lab position selection is so fucking random. I lack of 3-baseman so it's natural that 1-baseman learns 3rd base, but no, fuck you, I am centerfielder now. Goddamn.

Other than that, I'm in love with the game and I need a break from it, because I played it for 2 weeks straight like a second job. 

What I'd like to add:

- More random events. Just rare charities from players and occasional bench-clearing are not enough.
- More league modifiers after Winter Meetings (and option to increase or decrease the chance of them orruring in the save). 
- Salary cap option. Goddamit, never thought I'd ever be appologetic to Craig Breslow and Chaim Bloom.
- Player allegiance. It would be great if players had some kind of allegiance. It's funny how FA from NYY come to Sox that easy as well as ex-Sox players become Yankees. Rivalries are cool.

Under the guise of supposedly advanced managerial options, OOTP 26 is not a simulation — it’s just a random mess. The RNG engine is limited and shallow — everything boils down to having blue bars on player stats, and any real tactical depth has completely vanished. The result? A game stripped of any genuine strategy.

The AI is a disaster — especially when it comes to player development and logical roster building. As many players have pointed out, minor league stats don’t mean anything, and pitcher development under AI control is a total failure. This edition also feels painfully average — nothing in the game makes you go “WOW.”

OOTP 26 flaunts a flashy interface and multiple game modes… but it’s all just a façade. Behind it lies a mechanic where strategy loses to randomness, and managerial decision-making is purely illusory. When you can’t truly influence the simulation in a meaningful way, you’re left with nothing but frustration — and the feeling that it’s RNG, not you, controlling the outcome.

Good: Some upgrades compared to last year's version. Some TLC in regard to historical mode (updated splits, minors starting in 1901) and the development lab. Revamped ratings make the game more realistic and less gamey, I tend to not mind this. A significant number of useful players will be 45/80 overall and 50-rated players can be all-stars with the right individual ratings. 

Neutral: A significant amount of potential growth for players remains until their late twenties, mostly to enable the player to use the development lab to reach said potential. Players will most likely stay stuck at their current ratings when using the development engine only. Not the most realistic addition. 

Bad: Significant issues with AI-teams releasing viable prospects immediately after drafting them remain unsolved after months, despite patches indicating the contrary (this issue was not present in previous year's version). Nonsensical AI minor league promotion strategy. Trade AI remains mediocre and house rules are needed for a somewhat realistic experience. 

A hard pass until the developers can actually prove they have fixed issues with players being released without any reason.

This is only negative to hopefully motivate the staff handling this game to perform better oversight and communication. There are cheaters in the multiplayer "Perfect Team" tournaments that pad teams and play multiple accounts in live games, cheesing wins... and this mode is entirely pay-to-win, which sucks because this mode is a lot of fun.

The rest of "Perfect Team" is incredible and everything I've ever wanted from a sports sim... live interactive leagues with depth and strategy. As I type this, Mike Schmidt has just won the last two playoff games for me with walk-off homers in my first full season... one more win, and I'm in the series.

I love that. 

Just give us better ability to report bad actors and then do something about them. 

It's also worth noting, if you do buy this don't waste your time watching Twitch hoping to earn some free packs. The affiliates barely broadcast enough to do a day's worth... and the official channel hasn't broadcast enough to make the week reward in any of the last three weeks.  I wasted three weeks checking that twitch channel every couple minutes... and I have 3 unfinished weekly rewards sitting there never to be filled.

Bottom line: This game wastes time, is pay to win, has cheaters in the leagues and no ability to do anything about them or report them.

The twitch waste of time really pisses me off.

Under the guise of supposedly advanced managerial options, OOTP 26 is not a simulation — it’s just a random mess. The RNG engine is limited and shallow — everything boils down to having blue bars on player stats, and any real tactical depth has completely vanished. The result? A game stripped of any genuine strategy.

The AI is a disaster — especially when it comes to player development and logical roster building. As many players have pointed out, minor league stats don’t mean anything, and pitcher development under AI control is a total failure. This edition also feels painfully average — nothing in the game makes you go “WOW.”

OOTP 26 flaunts a flashy interface and multiple game modes… but it’s all just a façade. Behind it lies a mechanic where strategy loses to randomness, and managerial decision-making is purely illusory. When you can’t truly influence the simulation in a meaningful way, you’re left with nothing but frustration — and the feeling that it’s RNG, not you, controlling the outcome.
